revision.comment: Goldenburg111 moved page [[User:Goldenburg111/Playspace]] to [[User:Afb1302/Sandbox]]: moving into userspace for learning
revision.text:
A schizophrenic man who is undiagnosed begins to blog, and begins to remember the first voices he ever heard and what they said. A furious story unwinds from his mind and takes him, and us, to strange places.
The author sends us on a journey into his mind. Started from events he knows to be true and continuing on to things that no one has ever thought of before. He follows religions as far as he can go. Writes to new religions that don't yet exist. Crosses space and time, twice. Takes our souls and turns them into answers. All through science fiction.
As a writer I was first noticed in Elementary School when a poem I had written about driving to my grandmothers house won a contest. Again in High School my English teacher expressed interest in my writing. Again in College my Literary Class Professor noted my ability to write. Once full of material and in my late twenties I exploded into the book The Crayola: Tome if Infinite Will.
The book was converted to Adobe PDF years ago and the original was lost.
Feel free to use my dropbox download. But for whatever reason Wikibooks blocks dropbox. So I'll have to get back to you. Feel free to ask for it.
Thanks!

revision.comment: /* You have been warned */ new section
/* You have been warned */ new section

revision.text:
When we look at the world, it appears to be a seamless whole. This makes it difficult to understand, and sometimes even difficult to believe, that our visual perceptual experience is created through a series of smaller perceptions of simpler things. But that's how it happens.
Vision is turning light into something useful. In our retinas we have photosensitive neurons. They increase their firing rate when photons (particles of light) hit them. At a first approximation, you can think of the first layer of neurons as a bunch of pixels, encoding some color at some location. But this is just the first layer. After that, they start to detect higher level patterns.
One of the first discoveries was that there were certain neurons that detected lines at particular angles. That is, there would be a neuron that would increase its firing rate in the presence of line at, say, 90 degrees, but not at other angles. As a shorthand, we'll say that the neuron "detects" lines at 90 degrees. David Hubel and Torsten Weisel discovered this in 1958, studying the dog's visual system. They were exposing the dogs to images, and recording the activity of single cells in the visual pathway from the eye to the brain. The images weren't doing much, but when they moved the slides sometimes the neuron would go crazy. It finally dawned on them that the neuron was responding to the edge of the slide, not the picture in it! This is one of many stories in science of accidental discovery (Martinez-Conde & Macknik, 2014).
So what happens? Does the neuron increase firing only in the presence of lines at ''exactly'' 90 degrees? No. If the line is slightly off 90 degrees, the neuron will increase its firing rate to a lesser extent. The closer the line is to 90 degrees, the higher the firing rate. There are neurons for detecting angles of all orientations: some for 180 degrees, some for 30 degrees, etc. Each one has a particular "receptive field." With the information from all of these neurons firing, an cognitive system can tell with some good degree of accuracy the orientation of a line. Hubel and Weisel found that the further "upstream" you go, away from the retina and toward the rest of the brain, the more complex are the detections. That is, lines are fairly simple, but those lines are used by higher neurons to detect even more complex patterns.
'''Vocabulary'''
receptive field
'''References'''
Martinez-Conde, S. & Macknik, S. L. (2014). David Hubel's vision. "Scientific American Mind", March/April, 6--8.

revision.text:
='''Preamble'''=
This is the opening page to the Digital Media and Culture Yearbook 2014.
As the title suggests, this is a book which seeks to record contributions to the understanding of a specific set of topics, loosely grouped under the title "Digital Media and Culture", of particular salience to 2014.
It is put together through the combined talents and efforts of a cohort of students taking the FMS9A4 module during the Spring of 2014. The aim is, firstly, for students to record the content of their learning and their contributions to this book will reflect their studies on one of the featured themes. However, secondly and most importantly, the hope is that students will learn the values associated with working at different levels as individual researchers, as research teams, and as research communities. That is to say: producing knowledge; collaboration and sharing; and peer-reviewing the work of others for the good of the community. Students will thus gain hands-on experience of a wiki environment, within the auspices of one of Wikimendia's large projects (i.e. Wikibooks) and make something that adds to currents in the academic field of digital media.
[[User:GregXenon01|GregXenon01]] ([[User talk:GregXenon01|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GregXenon01|contribs]])
='''Chapters'''= *[[/Chapter 1: Technological Determinism/]]
*[[/Chapter 2: Online Identity/]]
*[[/Chapter 3: Always-on Culture/]]
*[[/Chapter 4: Cognitive Surplus/]]
*[[/Chapter 5: Crowdsourcing/]]

[[User:Connor Zahariev|Connor Zahariev]] ([[User talk:Connor Zahariev|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Connor Zahariev|contribs]])
[[User:Sophie Michele Addison|Sophie Michele Addison]] ([[User talk:Sophie Michele Addison|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Sophie Michele Addison|contribs]])

[[User:Katie chambers|Katie chambers]] ([[User talk:Katie chambers|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Katie chambers|contribs]])
[[User:Markconnor7|Markconnor7]] ([[User talk:Markconnor7|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Markconnor7|contribs]]) 14:25, 7 April 2014 (UTC)
This wikibook is being put together as an on-going a collaborative project by the following wikipedian contributors. Together, they form a cohort of students studying Digital Media and Culture as part of their degree programme in the Division of Communications, Media and Culture, The University of Stirling, Scotland, UK. Doubtless, there are other contributors within the Wikibooks and Wikipedia community who have contributed advice, support, suggestions and content in collaboration with these students. Your help and advice is most appreciated. Thank you!

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, GregXenon01!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
Hello - Linus [[User:LinusEDI|LinusEDI]] ([[User talk:LinusEDI|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/LinusEDI|contribs]]) 13:19, 18 March 2014 (UTC)
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 20:52, 10 March 2014 (UTC)
Hello Greg, good teaching today! == Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Ganeshprasadkp!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 20:54, 10 March 2014 (UTC)
== [[Kannada/Numbers]] == I have removed your signature from this recently created page. Wikibooks pages should not contain signatures because they are open works which anyone can edit. Comments on Discussion pages or the Reading Room can contain signatures.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 11:30, 11 March 2014 (UTC) Thank you for the guidance Xania. [[User:Ganeshprasadkp|Ganeshprasadkp]] ([[User talk:Ganeshprasadkp|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ganeshprasadkp|contribs]]) 06:17, 12 March 2014 (UTC) Xania, can you help me on an article in wiki? Link is: https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Kannada_proverbs This article is supposed to be deleted within few days because of lack of sources. How can I avoid the deletion? Actually I don't have any authorized sources for those. Can you help? [[User:Ganeshprasadkp|Ganeshprasadkp]] ([[User talk:Ganeshprasadkp|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Ganeshprasadkp|contribs]]) 06:24, 12 March 2014 (UTC)

page.title: Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Putting It All Together: A Dragon!

revision.comment: Adding a new module I created
revision.text:
{{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Procedural Eyeball |next=Image Editor |nextText=The UV/Image Editor }}
=Putting it all Together: A Dragon!= {{B3D:N2P/ForVersion|2.69}}
I downloaded Blender without knowing much about how to use it, probably like you. I hunted around for a good tutorial and found this one. It is teaching me wonderful things! I have diligently followed every lesson from the beginning, as I hope you have. Every lesson seems to contain some valuable technique. So now it is time to put it all together into a single project.
Hopefully, you now know * How to add objects, move and rotate them, scale them in various dimensions, and change their shape. * How to use proportional editing to change them even more. * How to parent, join and separate objects. * How to use materials and textures. * How to use images in materials. * How to use basic lights. * How to use modifiers including subsurf and array. * Basic use of curves * It will help if you know how to use a photo editor such as GIMP to produce seamless textures
This project will build on all that background. Since all those things have been covered before, this will not be a key-by-key tutorial but rather a description of the general steps to take to make the finished scene. __TOC__ ==Modeling from the Image==
[[File:Komodo Dragon (2007).jpg|thumb|300 px|left|Komodo Dragon]] [[File:Dragon 003.png|thumb|300px|right|Using cubes to model the dragon]] [[File:Dragon 008.png|thumb|200 px|left|The basic body smoothed.]] It happens that the Komodo Dragon is one of my favorite creatures. Let us start with that and let our imagination run wild. In the lesson on '''[[Blender_3D:_Noob_to_Pro/Modeling_a_Fox_from_Guide_Images|Modeling a Fox from Guide Images]]''' we learned how to make a beautiful 3 dimensional wolf from an image. (Yes, I know. The fox turned into a wolf. If you did that lesson you understand.) Here is a nice picture of a Komodo Dragon by wallygrom from [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Main_Page Creative Commons] with a proper license. We can then set that picture as a background image and apply the technique of starting with a cube and scaling it, extruding it, scaling again and so on. We only have one view, so our imagination and application of other pictures has to help with the top and end views, and we have to add a nice long tail. As you build your cubes keep in mind that you will have to create faces and extrude the legs so place a well sized face at the proper spot.
We will use the techniques we learned to split faces and add the legs. Be sure to provide a nice mouth to put teeth in later, and pay particular attention to modeling the claws. I modeled one entire foot and then duplicated it three times to have them all, and joined each one to the body at the appropriate spot.
Once you have outlined the dragon with the cubes, remember what we learned in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Detailing Your Simple Person 1|Smoothing Your Simple Person]]''' and apply subsurf modifier and smooth the entire thing. You can then push and pull on vertices to help make it look as good as possible. I wanted to try to maintain the look of an ordinary creature and stay close to my Komodo Dragon, rather than a huge fierce beast to take on St. George.
==Setting the Body Materials and Textures==
Use what we learned in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Image Textures|Image Textures]]''' to give the dragon his scales. The most used technique in this tutorial is: * Search [http://www.flickr.com/creativecommons/by-sa-2.0/ Flicker Creative Commons] for a properly licensed picture that has a good material in it. If you use Google or some other search, be sure that the picture you get is properly licensed if you plan to share the image. * If your image is NOT a single seamless texture, use photo editing software (such as GIMP) to produce a usable seamless file. ** Load the image into GIMP. Crop it to a reasonable size showing a relatively uniform texture. ** Choose ''Filters > Map > Make Seamless''. Other photo editors will usually have a similar operation. ** Save the image with a suitable file name. * Add a material and a texture using the image. Adjust the settings as needed to look good. * If you are following my steps, I have put all the textures in this article for you to copy if you wish. Click on the thumbnail image and go to the Wiki page from which you can download.
[[File:Flickr 2.0 lic Komodo Dragon SKIN.png|left|thumb|266 px|Fantasy Dragon Skin seamless texture]]You can just select a rectangular swatch of skin from the picture and use GIMP to make it seamless. But Komodo Dragons are a depressing color. For a fantasy creature we need a brighter skin! So you can play with GIMP Colorizer until you have a suitably colored swatch. I used red and gold, but use your imagination! This becomes the first material and texture for the dragon's body. It will probably be necessary to repeat the image several times in both the X and Y directions. I used X:6 and Y:2 in this particular case.
==Adding the Eyes== [[image:Dragon 009.png|thumb|300 px|left|The first rendering.]]The dragon needs suitably scary eyes. Hopefully you have already modeled eyes for the '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Procedural Eyeball|Procedural Eyeball]]''' tutorial. I chose the cat's eye. In '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Simple Vehicle: Some Assembly Required|Some Assembly Required]]''' we learned how to append a file. Append the Cat's Eye, and then work on the color textures until you have a suitably scary dragon eye. Then duplicate it and put one eye on each side of the dragon's head. I joined the eyes to the body, but you can also just parent them if you are careful. You will notice in later renderings that I kept playing with the eye color and position.
==A Dragon Needs Teeth and Claws== [[image:Dragon 025.png|thumb|300 px|left|Assigning texture to the claws]][[image:Dragon 026.png|thumb|100 px|right|Four rows of Teeth]] Using the technique from '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Multiple Materials Per Object|Multiple Materials per Object]]''' , isolate the claws and give them a nice shiny black material. Too much Specularity will make the claws look like plastic, too little will make them dull and uninteresting. I added just a little bit of Mirror also. It will be something to experiment with until you get the look you like. Click on the picture to enlarge it and see the setting I settled on. Remember that you have to select the area of the mesh and ASSIGN it to the material or you will wind up with a dragon that is black all over! (That is the voice of sad experience speaking).
A dragon needs teeth. A lot of teeth! Modeling all those teeth would be a big job. Fortunately we learned how to use array modifiers in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Building a House|Building a House]]'''. Add a cone, scale it down very small, and extrude some more parts so you can shape it into a nice curve. When you have a beautifully sharp tooth, add the Array modifier and make it into a whole row of sharp teeth. Then duplicate the whole thing three times, rotate it around as needed, and you will have four rows of teeth, enough for both jaws. This is why we left the mouth open when we made the original model.
==Horns, a Crest, and Nostrils==
[[image: Dragon 013.png|thumb|left|300 px|Using the Curve Modifier]][[image: Dragon 015.png|thumb|right|200 px|The color settings for the horns]][[image: Dragon 029.png|thumb|left|100 px|Nostrils]]Lets give the beast some horns. Here we can use what we learned in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Deforming Meshes using the Curve Modifier|Deforming Meshes using the Curve Modifier]]''' to make some gracefully curved horns. Just as in that lesson, add a cone and extrude segments to give a lot of vertices. Then create your Bezier Curve and set it as a modifier to the horn mesh. Properly done your horn will mold itself to the shape of the curve. Duplicate it and rotate it to fit the other side of the head and put them in place.
Animal horns are some of the most beautiful structures in nature. We should make a particularly pretty material for them. We can use the blending colorband as in the tutorial '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Basic Carpet Texture|Basic Carpet Texture]]''', updating it a bit for 2.69, to give the horns a nice color appearance. Then add '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Subsurface scattering|Subsurface Scattering]]''' as taught in that tutorial, with a lot of experimenting, until you get a really beautiful appearance. The settings I used are in the picture but it is fun to try different things.
An impressive crest should dominate the dragon's back. I found a picture of a basilisk lizard and used it as a background model for the crest. The Crest texture was produced in GIMP exactly the same way as the dragon skin texture.
Reptile nostrils are sort of nondescript, so lets make some nice nostrils like a snorting bull might have. You can use the technique from '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Spin a goblet|Spin a goblet]]''' to model one nostril, then duplicate it, rotate the pair until they look fierce, and give them a nice color like the dark red brown I picked. Then put them in place and parent them to the body.
Now you can render your dragon and see the basic body shape, but something is missing. What is it?[[Image: Dragon 016.png.jpg|thumb|center|400 px|Teeth, Claws, Crest and Horns]]
==Giving the Dragon Wings==
[[Image: Dragon 027.png|thumb|left|200 px|An attempt at wings.]]
The wings were the hardest part, because we have not had many tutorials in this series that dealt with the problems involved. I started with a cylinder object and went from there, joining other cylinders to it, and then selecting edges and using{{B3D:N2P/Do|FKEY}} to create faces. There may be other better ways to do it. I wanted the wing sail parts to be semi transparent and give an appearance of shimmering colors. Experimenting with the transparency and the materials as seen in the screenshot gave me some I liked pretty well. I am not completely satisfied with it but perhaps it is the best that can be done with the tools we have so far learned. Joining the wings to the body seemed to produce some distortions so I just parented both of them to the body object.
Now there is just one more thing that a perfect dragon needs.
==FIRE!== [[image: Dragon 023.png|thumb|right|300 px|Settings for flames]][[File:Flickr 2.0 lic flames.png|thumb|left|273 px|Seamless flame material]][[image: Dragon 017.png|thumb|left|100 px|Scaling the cylinders]] [[image: Dragon 017a.png|thumb|left|100 px|Distorting the cylinders]] Everybody knows that dragons breathe fire. It seems that there are many different ways to do flames in Blender. However, I am attempting to use methods covered so far in this tutorial series, so I wanted to experiment and see what could be done with just what we have learned. I came up with something reasonably close to flame breath using basic techniques. I started with a series of cylinder objects, scaled at one end until they are almost cones, and then stacking them inside each other. I used the proportional editing that we learned about in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Mountains Out Of Molehills|Mountains Out Of Molehills]]''' to pull and stretch into some more or less random shapes. I found the flame picture and turned it into a seamless material swatch. Then I wrapped it around my cones and began playing with the settings for transparency, and added an Emit setting just to see how it looked. (If you want to jump ahead refer to [[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Making Fire|Making Fire]] in the next section of this series.)
==Ground to Stand on==
[[image: Lava seamless texture.png|thumb|left|273 px|seamless lava texture]][[image: Seamless grass.jpg|thumb|right|300 px|seamless grass texture]]Now it is time to complete the scene by giving him something to stand on. Since his front feet are raised, put in a sort of lava flow for him. That seems appropriate for a dragon. Try Adding a series of cubes. Stack them up and pull them out of shape with proportional editing. Add a subsurf modifier, and then the set the lava rock as an image texture. Again I made a seamless material out of a photo.
Then create a plane and again use the proportional editor to make some nice hills. A seamless green grass texture repeated multiple times completed the ground.
==Lighting==
[[Image:Dragon 031.png|thumb|left|100 px|The No Shadow setting]]So far the lighting has just been the default point light. I think it is a bit more dramatic to use the Sun style of lamp. As we learned in '''[[Blender 3D: Noob to Pro/Light a Silver Goblet|Light a Silver Goblet]]''' go to ''Add>Lamp>Sun'' and place a sun type lamp rather high in the sky. You will notice that now you get two overlapping shadows, one from the Sun and one from the default point lamp. You could just delete the point lamp, but, to advance beyond what has already been covered, it is useful as fill lighting. You can select the point lamp, go to the properties panel and click on the light icon[[File:Blender-2.5 lamp radio button.png]]. Scroll down to Shadow and click No Shadow and the point light becomes a fill light. Setting the horizon color in the world panel [[File:Blender268TextureIconWorld.png]] is the last step to produce this scene.
=THE FINAL RESULT=
[[image:Dragon 028.jpg|thumb|center|700 px|The Final Result]]
I think it nicely combines pretty much all I have learned about Blender so far in the tutorial! If you want to try your hand at a project, it is not as hard as you might think. You and I have really learned a lot by going through the first two sections of''' Blender 3D:Noob to Pro'''. I thank all the authors who have worked hard to bring us to this point.
I challenge you to show off what you can do with your newly acquired knowledge and put your finished work up here. It will probably be a lot better than mine.
===Add your project below this line===
{{B3D:N2P/NAV |previous=Procedural Eyeball |next=Image Editor |nextText=The UV/Image Editor }}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Jason Evan Baldwin!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:57, 11 March 2014 (UTC)

{{Side note|side=right|{{Java Swings/Content}}}} This chapter explains how to separate Swing applications into a more maintainable triad of components: the domain model, the view of the user interface, and the controller that oversees these. A minimal class structure is shown below. [[File:Java Swings Wikibook, MVC class diagram.svg|center|600px]] The main application class is the controller: it creates a model object (which is Observable), and a view object (which is an Observer of the model). The controller adds the view as an observer of the model. When the model changes, it calls setChanged() and then notifyObservers(). This means that the model can react to user input. The controller doesn't touch the view (apart from instantiating it and giving it the model). The view has access to the model, including to change it.

{| style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; width: 242px; border: 2px solid #FFCC00; clear: right;" |- | {{User Google}} |- | {{user language|en|3}} |- | {{user language|es|N}} |}
== About the Me and the Book ==
I am the Director of the Texas Conference Adventurer Ministry. The Adventurer Club is my passion. Since I can remember I have been involved with the clubs in one way or another. I was introduced to the Adventurer Club when my oldest daughter was of adventurer's age, and just felt in love with the adventurers, and the adventurer's activities. I had so much trouble finding information and appropriate activities for Adventurers that I started collecting information. Years later, I felt the necessity to share this information with our staff in the Texas Conference. This book is the result of years of searching and collecting information. Please feel free to add more information or links to make this a great book to share with all of our Adventurers Friends.
[[User:Adalvis|Adalvis]]
== Club Life == I became a Master Guide at the young age of 16. Invested as Pathfinders Leadership Award (PLA) at Texas Conference Pathfinder Camporee in 2006. Invested as Pathfinders Instructor Award (PIA) at Oshkosh International Pathfinder Camporee in 2009. Invested as Adventurer Leadership Growth (ALG) at my local church in 2010
After my investiture as Master Guide, I was asked to be Master Guide Associate director at my local club.
* 1999 - 2005 Served as Adventurer Club Director for the Midnight Warriors in Alvarado Texas. * 2004 - 2007, Served as Keene Fort Worth Adventurer Associate Coordinator. * 2007 - 2011, Served as Keene Fort Worth Adventurer Coordinator. * 2011 - to present, Texas Conference Adventurer Director
MR.JOT.SINGH

On drawings, v<sub>a</sub> should be on the output of 3<sup>rd</sup> op-amp, that is on the anode side, left side, of diode. Cathode side, right side, is on virtual 0 V. [[User:DarkoS|DarkoS]] ([[User talk:DarkoS|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/DarkoS|contribs]]) 14:22, 11 March 2014 (UTC)
The author says "MOS are symmetrical devices, so we could replace the drain with the source without affecting the behavior of the device." but this is an over generalization. Many discrete mosfets have a body source-drain diode. They are definitely not symetrical. [[Special:Contributions/192.146.101.24|192.146.101.24]] ([[User talk:192.146.101.24|discuss]]) 20:49, 25 March 2014 (UTC)

LCR stands for Load Compliment Register. The use of this instruction results in loading of the value in two's complement format from the second operand register into the first. Basically, the value (number) loaded is the opposite sign of what was in the second operand register. That is, a negative 3, for example. will be made positive when loaded into the first operand register; and again for example, a positive 3, will become negative 3 when loaded into the first operand register.

{{#if:{{{1|}}}|[[Trainz/AM%26C/{{{3|}}}{{{1}}}|{{{2|{{{1}}}}}}]]|[[Trainz/AM%26C|AM&C]]}} [[Category:Trainz typing-aid templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Self-documenting templates|{{PAGENAME}}]]
;usage This template forms an internal link to the [[Trainz]] wikibook with parameter {{{1}}}, and incorporates an option to access a sub-sub-page given the optional 3rd default parameter: {{{3}}} as well allowing for as an optional pretty-link re-title parameter '2' allowing {{{2}}} and/or '|3=sub-page/' formatted link calls ... all forming the link and all links in the wikimarkup as:
*   [[Trainz/AM&C/{{{3|}}}{{{1}}} | {{{2|{{{1}}}}}}]]  * Users unfamiliar with wiki-markup parameter parsing, just focus on {{{2}}} or '|2=text' overriding the presented text of the link, * and {{{3}}}/ or '|3=sub-sub-linktext/' giving a prefix to a sub-sub-page, so the subject page is: : [[Trainz/AM&C/{{{3}}}/{{{1}}} | {{{2}}}]], pipe-linked as {{{2}}} : if and when given, {{{3}}}/ MUST HAVE a trailing '/' to form a proper link.   '''Example-1, expanded paste down:''' :This is because all template default parameters, formally 'numbered parameters' can also be specified like this: {{TL |1=Tips And Tricks |2=Tips }} which wiki-markup language is processed exactly the same as {{TL |Tips And Tricks |Tips }}. ;caution When using a template such as this which forms a link, it is best to NOT use spaces between the pipe characters "|" as done for clarity above. {{TrainzTip|Spaces in the 'pretty-text' part are fine! }} '''In-line Examples:''' * {{TL|Tips And Tricks}} links as: :::[[Trainz/Tips And Tricks|Tips And Tricks]] and the other formulation: :::[[/Tips And Tricks|Tips And Tricks]] both would. :But... is much easier to edit around on a page when trying to get the best prose presentation. * Similarly: :::{{TL|Tips And Tricks|Tricks}} links as if the constructs: :::[[Trainz/Tips And Tricks|Tricks]] and :::[[/Tips And Tricks|Tricks]] which is perhaps part of the phrase you want. * Sub-subpage links will mainly be needed in the forthcoming Errorfixing series of tutorials and the Programmed Instruction (Trainz A-Z) linked progressive tutorials off their own sub-TOC base page.

:Planned use of Sub-sub-pages... '''Better than splitting the book down the multiple tracks'''... we're going to make ''a lot of new pages'' in the PI tutorials! Whether for beginners or intermediate Trainzers, they'll all end in content creation and other advanced topics like TransDEM map generation anyway.

revision.comment: /* You have been warned */ new section

revision.text:
{{status|00%}}{{DISPLAYTITLE:Foundations of economics}} == Scarcity == Economics as a discipline would not exist without scarcity.
This is the fundamental problem that all societies face. It refers to the escess of human wants over what can actually be produced to fulfill these wants. Human wants are unlimited. On the other hand, the means of fulfilling these human wants are limited becacuse the resources available are limited. As a result, choices have to be made.
For example, society cannot enjoy all the books and all tables if wants because the number of trees required to produce these goods is limited. It somehow has to decide how many books and how many tables it wants to produce. If mroe tables are produced then fewer books will be enjoyed and vice versa. We define as the opportunity cost of a choice, the value of the enxt best alternative sacrificed . If, for example, by giving (or more correctly, "allocating") a tree to table produciton, one extra table is produced but 25 books need to be sacrificed, we say that the opportunity cost of producing one more table is 25 books.
=== Resources (factors of production) === Resources are also referred to as factors of production. They includje all inputs used in the production of a good or service. They are typically separated into the following categories. ==== Land and raw materials (natural resources) ==== These are inputs into produciton that are provided by nature, for example agricultural and non-agricultural land, forests, pastures, mineral deposits, oil, natural gas, lakes, and rivers. The world's land area and raw materials are limited. SOme resources, such as oil and coal deposits, are non-renrewable: if they are used now, they will not be available in the future. Other resources, for example forests (timber) and the stock of fish, are renrewable.
==== Labour (human resources) ==== Labour includejs all forms of human inputi, both physical and mental, into current production. The labour force is, at any point in time, limited both in number and in skills. The total number of people avilable for work is referred to as the labour force or working population.
==== Capital ==== Physical capital includejs manufactured resources; in other words, goods used to produce other goods. The world has a limited stock of capital (limited supply of factories, machines, tools, and other equipment). Note that the meainng of capital in economics is different from that used in ordeinary speech where people refer to money as capital.
==== Entrepreneurship ==== Entrepreneurship is related but not identical to management. When a new venture is being considered, risks exist. They involve the unknwon future. Someone must assess these risk and make judgements about whether or not to undertake them. The people who do so are called entrepreneurs. Entrpreneurship refers to the willingness and ability of certain individuals to take risks and to mobilise the remaining factors of production.
=== Related concepts === In addition to the ide,a of physical capital already mentioned, it is usef to includej natural capital and human capital. ==== Natural capital ==== Natural capital can be thought of as natural resources which may be improved upon or may be depleted. Thinking in terms of natural capital can easily accommodate another related concewpt, sustainability, which refers to the idea of preserving and even inccreasing or improving upon the avilable stock of natural resources.
==== Human capital ==== Labour may also be improved upon, in that the labour force may become mroe productive. The term human capital refers to the education, training and skills embodied in the labour force of a country. Even if the size of the labour force of an economy is constant over time, the stock of human capital may increase.
=== Other useful introductory terms === ==== Social sciences ==== Disciplines that symentically study human behaviour form different perspectives. Economics, pyschology, anthropoligy, political science, sociology, and history we all considered social sciences.
==== Models ==== ==== Normative economic statements ==== ==== Positive economic statements ==== ==== Economic goods ==== ==== Free goods ==== ==== Competitive market ==== ==== Ceteris paribus ==== ==== Rationality ====
== The fundamental questions of economics == == The production possibilities curve ==

page.title: Game Creation with the Unity Game Engine

revision.text:
{| width=100% |- | valign=top width=30% | __TOC__ | valign=top | '''Status: This class project is in its initial stage.'''
This book is the result of the course 'Introduction to Programming with Unity', taught in the [http://www.th-nuernberg.de/ohm/mediaengineering/ media engineering] program at Technische Hochschule Nuremberg. It is a [[Wikibooks:List_of_class_projects|class project]], hopefully turning into a real wikibook at some later point in time. |}
{{Reading level|Intermediate}} {{Book Search}} [[/Preface/]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}}
=== [[/Introduction|Introduction]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === This class is an introduction into the Unity Game Engine. Before we can get started creating games, we need to install the necessary software and get our environment set up. * Overview * Installation * Links
=== [[/Game1_VeganIsland|Game 1: Vegan Island]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === A vegetarian is stranded on an island full of violent plants.
=== [[/Game2_CubeWars|Game 2: Cube Wars]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Cubes vs spheres, its a cruel world out there.
=== [[/Game3_XtremeCurling|Game 3: Xtreme Curling]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === World championships in curling, a two player game, who will win the world championship.
=== [[/GameDevelopment|Game Development]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Here we start getting our hands dirty. Slowly we learn how to use Unity. * Content * Game Objects * Cameras * Assets Models Materials Textures * Animation * Scripting * Collision Triggers * GUI * Terrain * PhysiX nVidia
=== [[/2D|2D Games]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Developing 2D games has been made quite a bit easier with the new Unity engine. * Sprite Animation * Camera * Box2D
=== [[/Audio|Audio and Sound]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Every game needs audio and sounds.
=== [[/Networking|Networking and Multiplayer]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Multiplayer games are harder to create, but more fun to play.
=== [[/Mobile|Mobile Development]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Unity can also create games for mobile platforms like phones and tablets.
=== [[Cg_Programming/Unity|Shaders]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === There is already an excellent wikibook on shaders with Unity, see the chapter on Unity in the wikibook [[Cg_Programming/Unity|Cg Programming]]
=== [[/Finalizing|Finalizing]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} === Your game is ready, but some finishing touches maybe needed. * Optimizing * Deploy * Debugging
=== Additional Chapters === * [[/Appendix/Tricks|Tips and Tricks]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} * [[/Appendix/SourceControl|Source Control]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} * [[/Appendix/MathematicsPhysics|Mathematics and Physics]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} * [[/Appendix/AI|Artificial Intelligence]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}} * [[/Appendix/Other|Other]] {{stage short|0%|Mar 12, 2014}}
=== Appendices === * [[/Authors/]] * [[Wikibooks:Copyrights|Licensing]]
{{Subjects|Computer programming languages|Computer science|Games}} {{alphabetical|G}} {{status|0%}} {{SideBox|[http://stats.grok.se/en.b/latest90/{{FULLPAGENAMEE}} page traffic for 90 days]}}

page.title: Game Creation with the Unity Game Engine/Preface

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ = Preface = This book/class is supposed to give a hands-on experience related to programming with the Unity Game Engine. Different aspects will be looked at. Most likely this book will be outdated as soon as it is finished, but for a little while it may serve as an entrance to the world of game programming.
The idea behind this class project came from a colleague who suggested that most class projects produce really nice results, but usually disappear in some instructors' drawers. After reading on the possibility of using Wikibooks for class projects, we just had to give it a try.
== Getting Started == If you are new to Wikibooks, you might first want to look at [[Using Wikibooks]]. Details for creating a class project can be found at [[Using_Wikibooks/Class_Project_Guidelines|Class_Project_Guidelines]]. If you are completely new to Wikipedia, the [http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Tutorial Wikipedia tutorial] maybe helpful to you. If you like to upload images to wikipedia, use the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:File_Upload_Wizard File Upload Wizard]. However, only upload images if you created them and you own the copyright!
== Other Wikibooks == There are also other wikibooks on subjects related that are quite useful: *[[Game_Creation_with_XNA]] *[[Cg_Programming]] *[[C_Sharp_Programming]]
== Other Class Projects == Inspiration from successful class projects can be drawn here, which by themselves are also quite interesting and maybe helpful for this project: *[[Basic Writing]] *[[Handbook for Doctoral Students in Education]]
== Experience from the First Iteration == No experience yet.
<noinclude>
[[../|< previous]] [[../Introduction|next >]]
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>

page.title: Game Creation with the Unity Game Engine/Introduction

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ = Introduction = This class will be a tour of the Unity Game Engine. It will cover many topics, mostly just touching the surface. But there will be plenty of opportunity to dig deeper and learn more by doing.
This class is an introduction into the Unity Game Engine. Before we can get started creating games, we need to install the necessary software and get our environment set up.
== Overview == There are two reasons for this class: * create cool 3D and 2D games * learn how to use the Unity Game Engine
For me the second aspect is actually the more important one. .
=== Subchapter === If you want a subchapter, this is how it is done...
== Installation == How to install Unity, supported platforms, etc...
== Links == If you find a cool tutorial or a neat link, post it here for now:
Example of a www link: (http://www.ethority.de/weblog/social-media-prisma/)
== How to do referencing? == An example usage of a reference is :"The Social Web is a set of social relations that link people through the World Wide Web." <ref name="SocialWeb">Social web, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_web</ref>
It has to be distinguished from what is called the Web 2.0 <ref name="Web20">Web 2.0, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_2.0</ref>, a phrase termed by Tim O’Reilly <ref name="OReilly">Tim O’Reilly (2005-09-30). "What Is Web 2.0". O’Reilly Network</ref>. Whereas Web 2.0 is about technology, the social web is about people.
So for instance, the map of the Internet, maps machines:
[[File:Internet_map_1024.jpg|200px|Machines]]
Whereas, a maps of friends on Facebook (a social network) maps people:
[[File:Kencf0618FacebookNetwork.jpg|200px|People]]
<noinclude> == References == {{Reflist}}
[[../Preface|< previous]] [[../GameDevelopment|next >]]
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ = Audio and Sound = Every game needs audio and sounds. Good sound is a crucial part in a successful game. For this you need to learn to create sound and audio. Also finding free sounds is an important topic. Some of that information can be found in the wikibook <ref name="Game_Creation_with_XNA">Game Creation with XNA, https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Game_Creation_with_XNA</ref>. * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Audio_Sound/Introduction|Introduction]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Audio_Sound/Creation|Creation]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Audio_Sound/Synthesizer|Synthesizer]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Audio_Sound/Finding_free_Sounds|Finding free Sounds]]

[[../2D|< previous]] [[../Networking|next >]]
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>

__NOTOC__ = Source Control = Games usually are developed by teams. Very important for teams is source control. Here might be the place for a short introduction to your favorite source control system. A quick introduction to the idea behind source control systems can be found in the wikibook [[Introduction_to_Software_Engineering/Tools/Source_Control|Introduction to Software Engineering]].

page.title: Game Creation with the Unity Game Engine/Appendix/MathematicsPhysics

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ = Mathematics and Physics = Many games need some understanding of vectors, matrices and related mathematical concepts. Also, physics plays a key role in quite a number of games. A quick introduction to the ideas involved can be found in the wikibook <ref name="Game_Creation_with_XNA">Game Creation with XNA, https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Game_Creation_with_XNA</ref>. * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Introduction|Introduction]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Vectors_and_Matrices|Vectors and Matrices]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Collision_Detection|Collision Detection]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Ballistics|Ballistics]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Inverse_Kinematics|Inverse Kinematics]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Character_Animation|Character Animation]] * [[Game_Creation_with_XNA/Mathematics_Physics/Physics_Engines|Physics Engines]]
<noinclude> == References == {{Reflist}}
[[../SourceControl|< previous]] [[../AI|next >]]
{{BookCat}} </noinclude>

;usage This is an auto-categorizing template with no other purpose than to save user typing and memory efforts to add a page in up to four Trainz categories. It's primary use is to list the tagged sub-sub-page into a maintenance category.
This template should be used to categorize all sub-sub-Pages of the Trainz wikis; In some contexts (Trainz references for example) it will be conditionally automatically included. * To suppress the auto-category define the 'inhibit' parameter. : It is used by adding the template '''{{tlx|TRS-SubSubPg|[[m:pipetrick|sorting-pipetrick]]}}'''
to auto-categorize pages to '''[[:category:Trainz Sub-Sub-pages]]''' adding it alphanumerically sorted (by the pipetrick) to the list of sub-sub-pages located from other such declarations. : This schema is an administrative aid to making sure pages don't go orphaned, but creates a navigable list sectioned by page titles for the users to navigate. * Parameters 1, 2, or 3 may be given and will auto:prefix the word category: and colon to auto-form up to three other category links, letting one cut and paste line define up to four categories. [[category:Trainz Sub-Sub-pages|*sub{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:Trainz Templates|sub{{PAGENAME}}]] [[category:self-documenting templates|sub{{PAGENAME}}]]  
{{#if:{{{inhibit|}}}||[[category:Trainz Sub-Sub-pages|{{PAGENAME}}]]}} {{#if:{{{1|}}}|[[category:{{{1}}}|{{{pipe|{{PAGENAME}}}}}]]}} {{#if:{{{2|}}}|[[category:{{{2}}}|{{{pipe|{{PAGENAME}}}}}]]}} {{#if:{{{1|}}}|[[category:{{{3}}}|{{{pipe|{{PAGENAME}}}}}]]}}

=About Me=
My name's Greg, I live in Stirling (Scotland, UK) where I seem to spend a lot of my time sitting in front of screens jabbing at an array of plastic buttons. When not jabbing, I occasionally field the odd enquiry from clients, colleagues and general ne'er-do-wells. I enjoy my job, my family and my weekends.
I encourage students to post messages on my talk page.--[[User:GregXenon01|GregXenon01]] ([[User talk:GregXenon01|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GregXenon01|contribs]]) 15:28, 12 March 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: /* Numbers in the page names? */ New topic
revision.text:
This is the discussion/talk page for the Digital Media and Culture Yearbook 2014 [[User:GregXenon01|GregXenon01]] ([[User talk:GregXenon01|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/GregXenon01|contribs]]) 16:55, 12 March 2014 (UTC)
== Numbers in the page names? ==
Somehow, I doubt the necessity of explicitly numbering the subpages. What’s the reason of naming the page [[{{SUBJECTPAGENAME}}/Chapter 1: Technological Determinism|Chapter 1: Technological Determinism]] when it could be named simply ''Technological Determinism''?
In general, a wikibook is intended to be updated over the years, and at times, it may become necessary to shuffle the chapters. Naturally, when the page is named ''Example'', the link to it could be moved around the “Contents” freely. However, when the pages are named ''Chapter 3: Rat that ate the malt, Chapter 4: Cat that chased the rat,'' etc., inserting a new “Chapter 3” means that all the chapters down the line ''are to be renamed'' (old “Chapter 3” to “Chapter 4”, old “Chapter 4” to “Chapter 5”, and so on.)
Even if it’s not an issue for this particular wikibook, I’d rather stick to this particular convention, just in case.
— [[User:Ivan Shmakov|Ivan Shmakov]] ([[User talk:Ivan Shmakov|d]] ▞ [[Special:Contributions/Ivan Shmakov|c]]) 15:07, 2 April 2014 (UTC)

revision.text:
== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, JC death!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 21:04, 12 March 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: Warning about changing from UK to US English
revision.text: Please do not change spellings or words from British / International English to American English (or vice-versa) as you recently did on [[Anatomy and Physiology of Animals/Reproductive System]]. All varieties of English are welcome on Wikibooks and the original spellings used in a page should not be changed.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 21:08, 12 March 2014 (UTC)

revision.text: 'referenced_asset_filename' :This template produces the string "'referenced_asset_filename' (as appears above) with embedded single quotes and italics as a typing-aid to aid the [[Trainz AM&C]] volume of the [[Trainz]] Wikibook discussing esoteric repair and generation of the components of Trainz assets. This phrase will used extensively. [[Category:self-documenting templates|Tref]] [[Category:Trainz Templates|Tref]]

page.title: Trainz AM&C/Fixing Errors/Error: Could not load texture

revision.comment: /* Error: Could not load texture */ interim, composing
revision.text:
{{trainz-stub}} {{TRS-Errors}} ==Error: Could not load texture== Sometimes a committed asset will report a missing texture file with a file path referenced in the cache, the cab (database {{TG|J|*.JA file}}) resulting in no texture file in the ''open-for-edit asset folder''. This particular example suggests there are three possible fixes for this particular missing texture, so I'm going to cover them in order from the most difficult (cursorary mention) to possibly the easiest. == Replace the missing texture by making one== {{TrainzTip| : ''It is likely this example is after some early processing using PEV tools on the date of installation. I recollect that but also reason because most TRS2006 assets will not contain texture.txt files if they haven't been massaged to comply with later data standards. This evolution in data types and configurations is the cause of many errors, and we the user community demanding more and better graphics from Trainz are at fault in that! }} The first one way this asset might be repaired is to create an appropriate {{TG|T|*.tga (texture file)}} as is referenced in a {{Tref}}.texture.txt Trainz {{TG|I|INI file}}, which are listed in directory folders when opened for edit as {{Tref}}.texture.txt files. This option can range from the trivial (create 'black.tga', often for a shadow texture, a handle, step, or under body) to the very difficult (the texture is the multi-view wrap texture that creates the detailed surface appearance of an 3D asset, meaning it's the most complicated part of any set of textures. In the easy or simple case, one makes a small image file in Microsoft Paint, GIMP, or other such graphics drawing program using a power of two squared size such as 8x8px, 16x16px, 32x32px or the like, keeping in mind Trainz will complain if a texture is monotone, to create a solid color, use the 32x32px size and change a few pixels inside to give it a little imperfection texturing, as if it showed dirt or rust, etc. For a solid black handle, try a dark grey/charcoal for a few pixels 'deliberate imperfection'. Creating a more complicated texture is beyond 'Intermediate Trainz' so the best thing to figure out is when to put things on hold and look into the asset creation pages and consult those with experience before tackling such. But there is often another recourse, stealing the author's own texture from the author. [[File:Trainz error fixes (Error= Could not load texture ') kuid 523 23233 XING 2 US boom-01.png|thumb|center|800px|TRS2006-SP1 content manager and Notepad++ editor showing (Left) both the errors list and asset line, (right) The key portion of the modified confix.txt file with it's new description block, (2nd error, already repaired)]] Asset creators are human beings and like the rest of us take the shortest way to doing multiple tasks given two or three choices. In the case of the two road crossing assets ('Xing' often in Trainz) here with issues, they are part of a set downloaded not from the DLS (leaving Auran and N3V off the hook, at least from the point of view of not sourcing corrupted data) but sourced from a famous Trainzer community, TrainzProRoutes.com, with an equally good reputation. They were, as might be deduced looking at the install times, ''part of a kit or set of assets bundled together'' in one {{TG|Z|*.zip}} or {{TG|C|*.cdp) file as a group configured (type+region+kind+era+category-region) with the same look and feel, so naturally they tend to share textures. These I have because they were used in a number of period routes set in the early 20th century gotten from the DLS recently authored (sic) by gfisher, again a famed route builder—which is why they were recommended to me to study and steal from for my projects in the same sort of mileau. Of the four, the entity with the worst reputation is N3V/Auran! # Step one in reading this error message was to examine a similar asset by the same author. The explicit file was found in 'XING_2_US_315', which assuming they are a direct copy, makes the fix a matter of opening both for edit, then copying the missing file into the sub-folder where the ini file # [[file:Trainz_error_fixes (Error= Could not load texture ') kuid_523_23233 XING_2_US_boom-02+XING_2_US, (kuid_523_23233) (both fixed on CMP).png|thumb|center|800px|alt=showing both errors fixed|AFTER screenshot, ''take careful note'' of the installation dates, and modification times on the right pane, half of which shows the source file copied.
{{Bull}}The suspicious computer engineer in me suspects CMP had a hiccup, with multiple files indexing the asset, and initially indexed a temporary file it created twice or more, then when it moved the workfiles from the cache into the database, had deleted the reference it had made moments before over and over.]]

revision.comment: Fabartus moved page [[Trainz/tags/category-region tag]] to [[Trainz/tags/category-region tags]]: conform to default naming convention for tags
revision.text:
{{FUN-top|refs2=ORP-top}} ==About Category-region codes== {{Parent|{{TR|R|TBS}}|{{TR|R|config.txt files|p=config}}}} '''Category-region codes''' are a single ("UK") or multiple codes ("AU;DE;UK;US") in a quoted string that is included in the {{TL|config.txt file}} for user defined filters. * Assets with narrow single country scope would contain a single code after the tagname. * Assets which were widely found in many regions (e.g. ''''Caterpillar D7 bulldozer'''', will list the series of country codes of the region.) ** The codes have only a minor importance in Trainz and are primarily used in Trainz as a sort and selection criteria in user defined filters. ** Some {{TR|K|p=Kind specifications}} will generate an error if the tag is undefined ** These codes do show up under the region column in {{TA|Content Manager}} where they can be included in defining filters one can also use in {{TL|Surveyor}}. This eliminates looking at undesired assets when focuses on developing your routes. * For content that exists in multiple areas, when creating new assets, select appropriate codes in {{TA|Content Creator Plus}} (CCP) or hand edit them into the config.txt ini files. ; For example: a locomotive that was available in the United States and Canada would be specified as follows:
category-region     "US;CA" : One that was available in Australia, Canada, the United States and in the United Kingdom would be specified as follows:
category-region     "AU;CA;UK;US"
==Tables of codes== <big>'''The category-region codes below are in alphabetical order by sort criteria.
Legal codes that are recognized by Trainz are as follows:'''</big>
